newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS - Motorola profits lower, but above estimates.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Motorola profits lower, but above estimates.

text.p: Technology giant Motorola Inc., still battling the downturn in its key semiconductor business, on Monday reported earnings of $325 million, lower than last year but beating analysts' estimates.

Motorola said its earnings, equivalent to 53 cents a share, came on sales of $6.6 billion and included gains from the sale of an investment and favorable patent settlements. In the first quarter of 1996, Motorola earned $384 million, or 63 cents a share, on sales of $7.0 billion.
The company said the gains accounted for less than 10 percent of pre-tax profits, and analysts estimated that excluding the gains Motorola earned at least 48 cents a share.
Market analysts had predicted Motorola would earn 45 cents a share, according to estimates compiled by First Call.

The results also met analysts' expectations that the profit would exceed that of the fourth quarter of last year, when it earned $238 million, or 39 cents a share. But analysts said revenues were shy of expectations, which ranged from about $6.8 billion to $7.2 billion.

"The bottom line is these are pretty good numbers," said Mona Eraiba, an analyst for Gruntal & Co. "The margins are improving, they're bringing costs down and it's an improving trend. But revenue is the question mark right now."

Motorola said the decline in sales for the quarter reflected a 16 percent drop in sales of semiconductor products, and orders were off 5 percent. But the company said the segment returned to profitability from an operating loss in the fourth quarter of 1996, although the profits were lower than a year ago.

"While semiconductor sales and orders were lower than first quarter 1996 levels, orders improved from fourth quarter 1996, as the business emerged from last year's semiconductor industry recession," Robert Growney, Motorola president, said in a statement.
The company said its steps to reduce costs in several business segments were beginning to have a favorable impact.
"I think the bottom line is they were able to reduce their costs," said Chris Chaney, an analyst for A.G. Edwards. "Gross margin was up a couple of points and we didn't expect that."

Motorola said sales in its cellular products segment, recently hit by pricing pressure and stiff competition, increased by 4 percent and new orders increased by 3 percent. But sales in the messaging information and media segment, which includes the paging group, fell 7 percent, orders were up just 1 percent and operating profits were lower.
